image.altText: Mano Yogalingham smiles, dressed in a white shirt as he sits indoors.

props.synopsis: Friends of 23-year-old Mano Yogalingam told the ABC the young father arrived in Australia from Sri Lanka in 2013 and had been on a bridging visa for roughly 11 years.

title.children: Grief and shock in Melbourne after Tamil asylum seeker dies by self-immolation

image.altText: Max Chandler Mather CFMEU rally

props.synopsis: Greens leader Adam Bandt has defended his colleague's decision to attend a CFMEU protest where the prime minister was likened to Adolf Hitler, saying the event was "legitimate" despite the "offensive" comparison.

title.children: Greens leader defends MP's CFMEU rally attendance but says Nazi sign 'offensive'

image.altText: A woman smiling

props.synopsis: Polls put Kamala Harris slightly ahead of Donald Trump in the US election race. But there are two potential stumbling blocks that could up-end the contest once again.

title.children: Kamala Harris is ahead of Donald Trump, but two big wildcards could up-end the race

image.altText: A car is crushed by a tree

props.synopsis: A man has died and a female passenger is critically injured after their car was hit by a falling tree in Victoria, as destructive winds sweep across Australia's south-east.

title.children: Man dies after tree falls on car in Victoria, spot fires started in NSW

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation declined in July, as commonwealth and state rebates drove energy prices lower, the Bureau of Statistics said.

title.children: Inflation falls to 3.5pc in July as energy rebates help to push electricity prices lower

image.altText: Clover Moore against a pink background holding a microphone

props.synopsis: Sydney Lord Mayor Clover Moore has been heckled at a community forum, after claiming her council's work on laneways and small bars have put the city ahead of Melbourne.

title.children: Sydney's lord mayor heckled after claiming city ahead of Melbourne for nightlife

image.altText: Australian female para-swimmer Rachael Watson takes a breath during a race.

props.synopsis: Classifications are an essential part of the Paralympics, helping group athletes together based on similar levels of impairments to create an even playing field. But it's not always easy to understand — here's our guide to the basics.

title.children: Paralympic classification can be confusing — here's how it works

image.altText: Wheelchair rugby player Beau Vernon poses for a photograph on the court

props.synopsis: As Beau Vernon recovered from a broken neck, nurses told him he would never be able to get dressed without assistance. Now, he is preparing for his Paralympic debut.

title.children: Once a young footy star, Vernon enters Paralympics with determination and purpose

image.altText: the outside of Maroondah hospital. There is an ambulance parked out front.

props.synopsis: A back-up ambulance was forced to treat a patient in the corridors of Maroondah Hospital in Melbourne's east, when paramedics were told no emergency beds were available at the hospital.

title.children: Paramedics forced to call back-up ambulance while ramped at busy Melbourne hospital

image.altText: About a dozen student are seen talking in a courtyard, in front of a tall sandstone clock tower at the University of Melbourne.

props.synopsis: The federal government's plan to cap international student numbers has split the tertiary education sector, drawing uproar from prestigious urban universities but cautious optimism from their regional and suburban competitors.

title.children: The government's international student cap proposal angers sandstone universities, but smaller players stand to gain

image.altText: fed uni student frank dyer inside the ballarat foodbank centre picking up a can

props.synopsis: Replicating a mini supermarket, shelves are brimming with groceries from local and international big-name brands, giving dozens of vulnerable students participating in the trial the power of choice at no cost.

title.children: Free 'supermarket' for vulnerable uni students 'a blessing', participant says

image.altText: Fears Tasmania left exposed after AFP officers removed from Hobart's airport

props.synopsis: AFP officers have walked off the job at seven major airports around the country as part of ongoing industrial action.

title.children: AFP officers walked off the job from seven major airports yesterday, but didn't make their action public due to security concerns

image.altText: Bentinck Island fish traps from the air

props.synopsis: Traditional owners say World Heritage listing would help preserve Australia's largest archaeological site, an elaborate network of stone walls designed to trap fish at low tide in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: Calls to protect northern Australia's ancient stone wall fish traps from tourists, climate change

image.altText: An old stone building with a red dome

props.synopsis: A "devious" Adelaide woman who stole millions from the savings and super accounts of elderly victims, using some of the funds on hire cars and hotels, has not revealed what she did with all of the money, a court has heard.

title.children: 73yo 'con artist' swindled millions from vulnerable elderly victims in 'shocking' scheme, court told

image.altText: Michael Voss holds his phone up as two people scramble out of a Mercedes Benz crashed sideways in a residential street.

props.synopsis: Michael Voss conducted a citizen's arrest when he pinned a 16-year-old to the ground and waited for police. What is a citizen's arrest and would you do it?

title.children: What are the risks of a citizen's arrest like the one AFL coach Michael Voss made?

image.altText: Matthew Owies

props.synopsis: Goalsneak Matthew Owies will miss Carlton's elimination final against the Brisbane Lions after the AFL upheld his one-match ban for a dangerous tackle.

title.children: Blues forward Owies to miss finals clash over dangerous tackle, despite winning a free kick for it

image.altText: A photo showing a man wearing glasses and wearing a black baseball cap, ookingdirectly at the camera

props.synopsis: The NT's new CLP government has promised to curb soaring crime with tougher laws and enforcement. But the manager of an Alice Springs shopping centre has found pulling back on security, instead of increasing it, has worked better.

title.children: The new NT government plans to toughen crime laws, but this shopping centre is suggesting an alternative

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and wearing glasses looking at the camera with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: What was meant to be a dream holiday in Japan for Cassandra Nichterlein and her young family turned into a costly nightmare when their return flight from Japan was cancelled.

title.children: A family was left $7,000 out of pocket after a flight cancellation. Jetstar initially offered them $600

image.altText: Liz Ellis speaks in front of a microphone in a blue suit

props.synopsis: Despite boasting similar participation rates to Australian rules football, netball receives far less government support. Liz Ellis says that must change as Netball Australia prepares to host a 2027 World Cup and push its case for the 2032 Brisbane Olympics.

title.children: 'We've got to bang our own drum': Now is netball's time to be bold

image.altText: Stack of several thousand dollars worth of Australian $50 notes showing David Unaipon

props.synopsis: New analysis released by the super industry has found one in four workers is missing out on compulsory superannuation payments, with women and those in lower-paid jobs worst hit.

title.children: 'Leaves people poorer when they retire': Could you be missing out on super payments?

image.altText: Hayden Young in action for Fremantle

props.synopsis: Fremantle star Hayden Young was thought to be suffering a corked leg as he limped around in the final quarter against Port Adelaide, only for scans to reveal something far more sinister.

title.children: 'Not your normal sort of corky': Hayden Young attempted to play on broken leg to help Dockers reach finals

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed with tubes going into his nose and mouth.

props.synopsis: Hepatitis C attacked Dennis Maby's liver over two decades and nearly claimed his life. Now clear of the disease he's urging other people to get tested.

title.children: 70,000 Australians are estimated to be needlessly living with Hep C. They also likely don't know they have it

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: The US and UK elections this year are proving to be significant flex points, and that has consequences for us in Australia. But it also shows how clear values are the only workable response to chaos.

title.children: Australia is labouring through wrenching transitions, and there's only one way out of the chaos

image.altText: Rear view of woman in hospital gown sitting on bed.

props.synopsis: Australia's largest health and medical research funding body has recommended sex, gender, variations of sex characteristics and sexual orientation be routinely considered in health and medical research.

title.children: Medical research has a sex and gender problem. New standards hope to change that

image.altText: Boeing starliner

props.synopsis: With NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore stranded aboard the ISS for months, a decorated former astronaut tells the ABC they would know and have trained for the risks but the view is definitely worth it.

title.children: NASA's astronauts now aboard the ISS face 'untold consequences' for their future

image.altText: A blurred photo of a dog.

props.synopsis: Despite Instagram's policies against explicit content, the ABC has uncovered dozens of accounts on the platform — each with hundreds of followers — sharing images and videos of dogs being sexually exploited as well as other types of animal cruelty.

title.children: Instagram awash with easily accessible, 'horrific' accounts depicting bestiality

image.altText: Volodymyr Zelenskyy speaks into a microphone with one arm raised, in front of a blue background.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has defended Kyiv's surprise incursion into Russia's Kursk region after Russian officials decried the move as "playing with fire".

title.children: Zelenskyy defends surprise Kursk incursion after Russian official decries 'playing with fire'

image.altText: A man named Clifford Sunfly stands in front of a Toyota four-wheel drive.

props.synopsis: Ravaged by drug abuse, rampant unemployment and deep social dysfunction, Balgo is one of Australia's most remote communities. But there are opportunities on the horizon, as a community with ancient traditions looks to a modern future.

title.children: The enormous mission to get residents employed in one of Australia's most remote communities

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: Rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve and other central banks will create a near-irresistible pressure for Australia's Reserve Bank to follow, potentially very soon.

title.children: Interest rate cuts in the US should mean cuts in Australia too — perhaps quickly

image.altText: Burnt remains of an e-bike

props.synopsis: A 15-year-old boy was heading to school on an e-bike in Alexandria when the lithium-ion battery went into thermal runaway and exploded. It comes a day after firefighters put out a major fire at a home in Merrylands that was also caused by a faulty battery.

title.children: Firefighters battle two e-bike battery fires in Sydney in two days

image.altText: Angie Ballard in racing wheelchair faces down wearing helmet and glasses, on a racing track.

props.synopsis: As she heads into an incredible seventh Paralympic Games, wheelchair racing champion Angie Ballard reflects on her journey to get here and her feelings about leading the Australian team into Paris.

title.children: From panic attacks to sponsorship woes, Paralympic champion Angie Ballard has overcome challenges for her seventh Games

image.altText: Close up of small furry animal

props.synopsis: Poison-laced food used to kill rabbits is being distributed in a region where work is underway to restore the population of an endangered species equally susceptible to the bait.

title.children: Poison-laced carrots 'a risk' to endangered bandicoots in Adelaide Hills

image.altText: Chappell Roan performs onstage during Lollapalooza at Grant Park on August 01, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois.

props.synopsis: With pop superstar Chappell Roan speaking out repeatedly against "creepy" behaviour from fans, we unpack what celebrities do and don't owe their audiences.

title.children: Chappell Roan wants fans to back off. Do celebrities owe us anything?
